docs.lead_paragraph: Ned McWherter, a sharecropper's son who as governor of Tennessee cajoled the legislature into passing a sweeping health care overhaul, making it the first state to offer health insurance to every uninsured person who wanted it, died on Monday in Nashville. He was 80. The cause was cancer, his family said.

headline.main: Ned McWherter, a Tennessee Governor, Dies at 80

docs.abstract: Ned McWherter, former governor of Tennessee, dies at age 80; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Oxygen) TORI & DEAN: STORIBOOK WEDDINGS Tori Spelling and her husband, Dean McDermott, left, move from inn keeping to event planning in this new reality series in which they help soon-to-be-married couples fulfill their visions of the perfect wedding day, assisted by the art director and interior designer James McGowan. Their first challenge: dog-themed nuptials for Samantha and Steven, who want a wedding based on their mutual love of pugs and that celebrates the traditions of their Jewish faith. But there are challenges that Ms. Spelling could never have anticipated. For instance, what is the correct size for a pug's yarmulke? 9:30 A.M. (CUNY) CITY TALK Doug Muzzio hosts the conclusion of ''From Shirtwaist to Wisconsin: Labor Unions and the American Worker,'' repeated at 4:30 and 9:30 p.m., which explores New York State's fiscal crisis, pensions, health insurance and setbacks in the labor cause. Ed Ott, the former executive director of the New York City Central Labor Council; Arthur Cheliotes, president of the Communications Workers of America Local 1180; and the historian Joshua Freeman offer opinions.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday Senate Democrats conceded defeat in the battle of how to pay for repealing the expanded 1099 reporting provision that passed last year as part of the Affordable Care Act but which many small-business owners consider burdensome. In voting to approve the bill, the Senate agreed to adopt a House Republican measure that Democrats viewed as an effort to undermine their health care law. Nonetheless, the bill passed the Senate by a lopsided 87 to 12 - with most Democrats voting in favor. Shortly after the vote, the White House signaled that President Obama would sign the repeal.

headline.main: 1099 Repeal Passes Senate, Heads to White House

docs.abstract: President Obama is expected to sign the measure.
docs.snippet: President Obama is expected to sign the measure.

docs.lead_paragraph: You can see the logic. Old people with dementia can become frightened and restless, angry or agitated. Reiki, a Japanese healing practice that supposedly channels a universal energy, is said to be soothing and deeply relaxing. So why not offer reiki to elderly dementia patients?

headline.main: For Patients With Dementia, Hands-On Comfort

docs.abstract: Can reiki soothe elderly patients with dementia?

docs.lead_paragraph: Just days after the Obama administration unveiled regulations on how doctors and hospitals can band together to offer coordinated care, Kaiser Permanente will open on Tuesday a demonstration center near the Capitol Building to show what it believes such coordination should look like.

headline.main: Kaiser Permanente Opens Clinic in Washington

docs.abstract: Kaiser Permanente is expanding on the East Coast, hoping to make inroads with lawmakers on Capitol Hill and elsewhere.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans in the House of Representatives are poised to place a dramatic political bet.

headline.main: Republicans Bet Public Will Reward Them for Proposing Cuts

docs.abstract: House Republicans will unveil a 2012 budget that bets voters are ready to accept tough changes and trillions in cuts to some of the nation's sacrosanct social programs.
